keyFacts: This is a standard Bureau of Prisons policy document (PS 5500.14) on firearms and badges, originally issued in October 2012.
The document includes sign-in sheets for mandatory SHU training dated June 6, 2019, and for Quarter #3 of 2019 (June 9 - September 7), indicating it was active policy during Epstein's incarceration.
The policy strictly governs when and how prison staff can use firearms, including to prevent escapes, loss of life, or to maintain control of the institution.
The policy requires immediate written reporting to the Warden upon the discharge of any firearm, whether on or off duty (except for training).

The document lists numerous other institutional program statements covering areas like suicide prevention, sexual abuse prevention, inmate discipline, and use of force, which are relevant to the overall prison context of the Epstein case.
The document is a standard Bureau of Prisons policy manual chapter on the use of firearms and badges by staff, dated October 19, 2012.
It outlines strict rules for firearm use, authorizing it only to prevent escapes, prevent loss of life/serious injury, protect government property, and maintain/restore control of an institution.
The policy specifies that firearms must not be used against inmates sentenced under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act.
It details specific scenarios for escape prevention at different types of facilities (walls, fences, MCCs/MDCs, minimum security) and during transport.
The policy includes requirements for verbal warnings and warning shots in most situations, with exceptions for imminent danger.
This is a Bureau of Prisons policy document (PS 5500.14) dated October 19, 2012, outlining rules for staff use of firearms.
The document defines when firearms can be used: to prevent escapes, prevent loss of life/serious injury, protect government property, and maintain/restore control of an institution.
It details specific scenarios for firearm use, including at perimeter walls, during escorted trips, and in hostage situations where only the Warden may authorize use.
The policy prohibits warning shots in many situations due to risk to innocent bystanders and outlines strict reporting requirements for any firearm discharge.
The document includes procedures for armed escorts on commercial aircraft and the issuance/use of identification badges for staff carrying firearms.

This is a general Bureau of Prisons policy document (Program Statement 5500.14) dated October 19, 2012, not a document specific to Jeffrey Epstein or his case.

The policy strictly defines when staff may use firearms: to prevent escapes, prevent loss of life/serious injury, protect government property under specific conditions, and maintain/restore control of an institution.
It details extensive rules for verbal warnings and warning shots, which are generally required before shooting a subject unless there is an imminent threat of death or serious injury.
The policy explicitly prohibits using firearms against an inmate recognized as a potential escapee if that inmate was sentenced under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act.
It includes procedures for armed escorts during commercial air travel and mandates written reports for any discharge of a firearm, whether on or off duty (excluding training/recreation).
The document is a Bureau of Prisons policy statement dated October 19, 2012, governing the use of firearms by staff.
It defines the 'escaping inmate standard,' allowing firearm use during continuous pursuit of an escapee from an institution, transport vehicle, or outside facility.
Firearms may be used to prevent loss of life or serious physical injury, protect government property under specific conditions, and maintain or restore control of a correctional institution.
The policy includes specific reporting requirements mandating a written report to the Warden upon any discharge of a firearm, whether on or off duty (excluding training/recreation).
It addresses armed escorts on commercial aviation, requiring staff to notify carriers and follow federal regulations (14 CFR Parts 108.11 and 108.21).
